00001 #ifndef MICRO_ALLOCATOR_H
00002 
00003 #define MICRO_ALLOCATOR_H
00004 
00041 // This code snippet provides a high speed micro-allocator.
00042 //
00043 // The concept is that you reserve an initial bank of memory for small allocations.  Ideally a megabyte or two.
00044 // The amount of memory reserved is equal to chunkSize*6
00045 //
00046 // All micro-allocations are split into 6 seperate pools.
00047 //    They are: 0-8 bytes
00048 //              9-32 bytes
00049 //              33-64 bytes
00050 //              65-128 bytes
00051 //              129-256 bytes
00052 //
00053 // On creation of the micro-allocation system you preserve a certiain amount of memory for each of these banks.
00054 //
00055 // The user provides a heap interface to callback for additional memory as needed.
00056 //
00057 // In most cases allocations are order-N and frees are order-N as well.
00058 //
00059 // The larger a buffer you provide, the closer to 'order-N' the allocator behaves.
00060 //
00061 // This kind of a micro-allocator is ideal for use with STL as it does many tiny allocations.
00062 // All allocations are 16 byte aligned (with the exception of the 8 byte allocations, which are 8 byte aligned every other one).
00063 //
00064 
00065 #ifdef __cplusplus
00066 
00067 #ifdef WIN32
00068         typedef __int64                         NxI64;
00069         typedef signed int                      NxI32;
00070         typedef signed short            NxI16;
00071         typedef signed char                     NxI8;
00072 
00073         typedef unsigned __int64        NxU64;
00074         typedef unsigned int            NxU32;
00075         typedef unsigned short          NxU16;
00076         typedef unsigned char           NxU8;
00077 
00078         typedef float                           NxF32;
00079         typedef double                          NxF64;
00080 
00081 #elif LINUX || defined(__linux__)
00082         typedef long long                       NxI64;
00083         typedef signed int                      NxI32;
00084         typedef signed short            NxI16;
00085         typedef signed char                     NxI8;
00086 
00087         typedef unsigned long long      NxU64;
00088         typedef unsigned int            NxU32;
00089         typedef unsigned short          NxU16;
00090         typedef unsigned char           NxU8;
00091 
00092         typedef float                           NxF32;
00093         typedef double                          NxF64;

00160 namespace MICRO_ALLOCATOR
00161 {
00162 
00163 // user provided heap allocator
00164 class MicroHeap
00165 {
00166 public:
00167   virtual void * micro_malloc(size_t size) = 0;
00168   virtual void   micro_free(void *p) = 0;
00169   virtual void * micro_realloc(void *oldMen,size_t newSize) = 0;
00170 };
00171 
00172 class MemoryChunk;
00173 
00174 class MicroAllocator
00175 {
00176 public:
00177   virtual void *          malloc(size_t size) = 0;
00178   virtual void            free(void *p,MemoryChunk *chunk) = 0; // free relative to previously located MemoryChunk
00179   virtual MemoryChunk *   isMicroAlloc(const void *p) = 0; // returns pointer to the chunk this memory belongs to, or null if not a micro-allocated block.
00180   virtual NxU32           getChunkSize(MemoryChunk *chunk) = 0;
00181 };
00182 
00183 MicroAllocator *createMicroAllocator(MicroHeap *heap,NxU32 chunkSize=32768); // initial chunk size 32k per block.
00184 void            releaseMicroAllocator(MicroAllocator *m);
00185 
00186 class HeapManager
00187 {
00188 public:
00189   virtual void * heap_malloc(size_t size) = 0;
00190   virtual void   heap_free(void *p) = 0;
00191   virtual void * heap_realloc(void *oldMem,size_t newSize) = 0;
00192 };
00193 
00194 
00195 // creates a heap manager that uses micro-allocations for all allocations < 256 bytes and standard malloc/free for anything larger.
00196 HeapManager * createHeapManager(NxU32 defaultChunkSize=32768);
00197 void          releaseHeapManager(HeapManager *heap);
00198 
00199 // about 10% faster than using the virtual interface, inlines the functions as much as possible.
00200 void * heap_malloc(HeapManager *hm,size_t size);
00201 void   heap_free(HeapManager *hm,void *p);
00202 void * heap_realloc(HeapManager *hm,void *oldMem,size_t newSize);
00203 
00204 void performUnitTests(void);
00205 
00206 //
00207 
00208 }; // end of namespace

00210 extern "C" {
00211 #endif       // #ifdef __cplusplus
00212 
00213 // C interface
00214 typedef void* (*micro_heap_malloc)(size_t);
00215 typedef void  (*micro_heap_free)(void*);
00216 typedef void* (*micro_heap_realloc)(void*, size_t);
00217 
00218 extern void  micro_allocator_init(micro_heap_malloc m, micro_heap_free f, micro_heap_realloc r);
00219 extern void  micro_allocator_destroy();
00220 
00221 extern void* micro_malloc(size_t size);
00222 extern void  micro_free(void* p);
00223 extern int   micro_was_allocated(void* p);
00224 
00225 #ifdef __cplusplus
00226 }
00227 
00228 class CMicroHeap : public MICRO_ALLOCATOR::MicroHeap
00229 {
00230 public:
00231   micro_heap_malloc m;
00232   micro_heap_free f;
00233   micro_heap_realloc r; 
00234 
00235   CMicroHeap(micro_heap_malloc _m, micro_heap_free _f, micro_heap_realloc _r) 
00236     : m(_m), f(_f), r(_r) {}
00237   inline void* micro_malloc(size_t size) { return m(size); }
00238   inline void  micro_free(void *p) { f(p); }
00239   inline void* micro_realloc(void *oldMen,size_t newSize) { return r(oldMen,newSize); }
00240 };
